text: Many consider this to be the best game in the franchise, though I have a soft spot for the first game which may still be my favorite. These games just know how to pull you in their different stories and mysteries. Often times I would try to figure out the conclusion in advance with many layers of twists, only for there to be that one extra layer I didn't see coming. Godot was a big highlight in T&T... I feel like drinking a nice cup of coffee now.
author: SupraDarky

author: Medal Melodies

text:
T+T Spoilers
.
.
.
.
I think the main idea behind how Godot acted as a prosecutor was to hint that he isn't really a prosecutor, and his main objectives for becoming a prosecutor was to humiliate Phoenix for failing to protect the love of his life, and protect Maya. 
I'd say calling him "Trite" and throwing coffee at him is a solid way of meeting one of those two goals. Godot succeeded at the other one in the final trial too, as well as getting revenge for Mia. I can't remember exactly why it had to be then, but it probably had something to do with that obscure plan and the possibility of him getting away from it without being fingered for murder.
That said, he was my favorite prosecutor to be up against because he was mostly chill even if he was demeaning Phoenix. He did his part to guide Phoenix (albeit in a tough-love kind of way) to the truth, and the only difference there was that instead of being behind the defense booth with him, he was at the other end of the court room. He was never actually on top of the case like Edgeworth and Von Karma, and investigated the case much like how Phoenix did. In court, he made sure that Phoenix backed up his bluffs with evidence rather than just letting him control the case with them.
Finding out the truth at the end was worth it, because after a whole game of belittling and demeaning you, Godot finally showed respect and called Phoenix by his actual name. I don't think he's a bad character, just a bad prosecutor, and there's a good reason for it.
author: Godot
